data.title: How LangChain Found a Trusted Partner for Their Sandbox Needs
data.snippet:
As a leader in open‚Äësource agent development, LangChain‚Äôs bread and butter is building, orchestrating, and deploying agents seamlessly for developers and non‚Äëtechnical users alike. To advance this mission, Brace Sproul, Head of Applied AI, and his team built a cloud‚Äëhosted coding agent that runs autonomously end to end. To open-source it reliably, they needed to nail one thing: their sandbox partner. [...] And the team doesn‚Äôt stop at attentive support. They continuously evolve the platform based on LangChain‚Äôs feedback. By actively seeking input and implementing improvements quickly, Daytona keeps LangChain focused on their core projects and pushes them further ahead in the fast-moving AI space.

#### The fact that Daytona is always so engaged and responsive is one of the main reasons why we chose them. Working with them has been seamless.

Brace Sproul

Head of Applied AI at LangChain

###### 03 -- RESULT

### LangChain Spins Up 4000 Sandboxes Every Month with Daytona [...] langchain.com

langchain.com

Linkedin

Linkedin

Linkedin

Learn how the leading open-source agent engineering platform partnered with Daytona to ensure secure, instant, and persistent sandboxes for their production-ready coding agent.

#### Our mission is to be the one place developers go for all their agent needs. Daytona is the only tech partner that could support our sandbox needs and make this possible.

Brace Sproul

Head of Applied AI at LangChain

###### 01 -- CHALLENGE

### Deploying Open-Source Coding Agents Called for a Reliable Sandbox Infrastructure Partner

data.title: "Open SWE: A coding agent built on Langgraph, explained by Brace ...
data.snippet:
During the "Ambient Agents" meetup last week, Brace Sproul gave us a walkthrough of Open SWE, a coding agent built on Langgraph. Open SWE monitors GitHub issues. When it gets a new one assigned, it kicks off a multi-agent architecture with a Manager, Planner, and Programmer. It can receive messages from users at any time during the process and incorporate them into the state. Check out the slides for diagrams explaining each agent:  And the code:  I found the takeaways really interesting: \ Summarization is hard: Especially with code changes that can get quite long, you literally can't send the entire context history to the LLM, and highly detailed old diffs may distract it. IIRC, the agent sends the last 20 messages, and summarizes the changes before. \ Agentic > hard coded: Open SWE [...] # "Open SWE: A coding agent built on Langgraph, explained by Brace Sproul"

This title was summarized by AI from the post below.

Pamela Fox

I like to learn, teach, and create.

 Report this post [...] the changes before. \ Agentic > hard coded: Open SWE tends to use the agentic approach of "here are your tools, pick which one to use" for almost all tasks. Except for one.. \ Explicit error handling: When an error happens, Open SWE stops everything and focuses on resolving the error. Otherwise, it could get too far afield and be unable to get back to a good place to solve the error. (Hopefully I didn't mis-represent anything I heard!) #Langchain #Langgraph

data.title: Dr. R.C. Sproul ‚Äì LifeCoach4God
data.snippet: but that God must give what He commands. It announces, not merely that men must come to Christ for salvation, but also that they cannot come unless Christ Himself draws them. Thus it labours to overthrow self-confidence, to convince sinners that their salvation is altogether out of their hands, and to shut them up to a self-despairing dependence on the glorious grace of a sovereign Saviour, not only for their righteousness but for their faith too. [...] is busy doing His work through their words, visiting sinners with salvation, awakening them to faith, drawing them in mercy to Himself. [...] ‚ÄúThese and the like things doth the Lord Christ continually declare, proclaim, plead and urge upon the souls of sinners‚Ä¶. He doth it in the preaching of the word, as if he were present with you, stood amongst you, and spake personally to every one of you‚Ä¶. He hath appointed the ministers of the gospel to appear before you, and to deal with you in his stead, avowing as his own the invitations which are given you in his name, 2 Cor. v. 19, 20.‚Äù

data.title: Build a Generative UI App in LangGraph - YouTube
data.snippet:
# Build a Generative UI App in LangGraph
## LangChain
167000 subscribers
746 likes

### Description
41777 views
Posted: 13 Mar 2025
Generative UI in LangGraph Docs: 

LangGraph Generative UI Examples: 

`npx create-agent-chat-app`: 

Agent Chat UI: 

Agent Chat Repo: 

Presenter: Brace Sproul [...] what's up everyone it's brace from Lang chain and I'm super excited to show off our new native support for generative UI in langra this is essentially an API we've added which allows you to directly register UI components with your langra server and then inside of nodes uh yield these components or push them to State and then on the client right here you can access those components which have pushed which have been pushed to to the state by your agent and render them directly to the user so we see I sent this query show me places to stay in New York for eight people that called a travel agent which extracted some details from my query like the location New York the number of guests8 it then called the list accommodations tool and with calling this tool um it triggered the uh ui. push

data.title: [PDF] Reflections of Ludwig Edelstein's life and work in his extant ...
data.snippet: poor timing of the Regents‚Äô decisions would be a recurring event throughout the controversy, and Edelstein would later curse their delay with decision making as a ‚Äòdevilish trick‚Äô.34 However, Sproul did not realise the importance of this first misjudged timing, nor did he even consider the harmfulness of the oath itself. David Gardner contends that Sproul thought that the oath would solve several issues, and did not contemplate that it would actually cause much greater difficulties.35 This was a tactical decision aimed at confirming public confidence in the university during a period of insecurity about communism, and alleviating internal tensions.36 It was also supposed that the oath would help prevent outside interference into the university‚Äôs business. As David Caute depicts it, it was [...] (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2003), 30. 28 Robert Gordon Sproul (1891-1975) was the eleventh President of the University of California, and held this position for twenty eight years: W. D. Hand, ‚ÄòRobert Gordon Sproul (1891-1975)‚Äô, Western Folklore, 35, 1, (1976), 46. For further biographical information, see G. Pettitt, Twenty-eight Years in the Life of a University President (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1966). 29 Gardner, California Oath, 27. 30 Kerr, Gold and the Blue, Vol. II, 30. 31 Gardner, California Oath, 24-27. 32 G. Stewart, The Year of the Oath (New York: Doubleday and Company Inc, 1950), 28. 18 orchestrated in this manner to minimize faculty resistance, causing bitterness and distrust.33 The poor timing of the Regents‚Äô decisions would be a recurring [...] lectures on campus, which made front page news in the national press.26 Both these events and their coverage in the press alarmed the Regents, and they were discussed in their meeting of 25 March 1949. It was in this meeting that the loyalty oath was first proposed. It was physically produced by the university‚Äôs comptroller James Corley, before being presented by the university‚Äôs President,27 Robert Gordon Sproul.28 The Regents were receptive towards the oath,29 and it was passed unanimously.30 The timing of these events was significant ‚Äì the oath was not proposed while the press were present, only Sproul, the Regents, and the Secretary of the Regents were in the room at the time.31 The faculty did not hear anything about the decisions made at this meeting until a notice appeared in the
